title: 112_hr3783
content: The "Countering Iran in the Western Hemisphere Act of 2012" acknowledges the US interests in the Western Hemisphere and Iran's efforts to build diplomatic and economic ties with Latin American countries to counter international sanctions and oppose Western influence. Additionally, the Act highlights the Department of State's concerns about Hezbollah, supported by Iran, being a highly capable terrorist group with significant resources. The Iranian Islamic Revolutionary Guard Corps (IRGC) Qods Force has a long history of supporting Hezbollah with guidance, funding, weapons, and operatives stationed in foreign embassies and institutions to build relationships, including in Latin America. The Department of the Treasury placed sanctions on the IRGC and its Qods Force in 2007 for their support of terrorism. The IRGC and its Qods Force have been involved in terrorist attacks, including the 1994 AMIA Jewish Community Center attack in Buenos Aires. Iranian intelligence agents have been linked to Hezbollah activities in Latin America, with Iran increasing its diplomatic missions in the region. Iran has built cultural centers and embassies in Latin America to support Hezbollah and other proxies. Hezbollah and Iranian proxies in Latin America engage in illicit activities such as drug trafficking, arms trafficking, money laundering, and providing support to terrorists. Bolivia, Cuba, Ecuador, Nicaragua, and Venezuela support Iran in evading sanctions and expanding economic ties. The U.S. Drug Enforcement Administration found that almost half of foreign terrorist organizations operate in the region. In October 2011, two men were charged by the United States for conspiracy to murder a foreign official using explosives in an act of terrorism. One of the men, Manssor Arbabsiar, traveled to Mexico to hire someone in the narcotics business to carry out the assassination of the Saudi Arabian Ambassador in the United States. Despite only engaging with a DEA informant posing as a drug cartel associate, Arbabsiar believed he was working with a Mexican drug trafficking organization. In February 2011, the Department of the Treasury shut down the Lebanese Canadian Bank, leading to the indictment of Ayman Joumaa in December 2011 for drug trafficking and money laundering. The United States aims to counter Iran's presence in the Western Hemisphere. The United States aims to counter Iran's presence in the Western Hemisphere by collaborating with allies and partners to deter threats from Iran, the IRGC, the IRGC's Qods Force, and Hezbollah. Definitions include the Western Hemisphere as the United States, Canada, Mexico, the Caribbean, South America, and Central America. The relevant congressional committees are the Committee on Foreign Affairs of the House of Representatives and the Committee on Foreign Relations of the Senate. A strategy to address Iran's growing hostile presence in the Western Hemisphere is required within 180 days of the enactment of this Act by the Secretary of State. The Secretary of State must assess threats posed by Iran in the Western Hemisphere and submit a strategy to address Iran's hostile presence. The strategy should include details on Iran, the IRGC, Hezbollah, and other terrorist organizations in the region, including their leaders, objectives, financial networks, and trafficking activities. The curr_chunk describes the presence of Iran, the IRGC, Hezbollah, and other terrorist organizations in the Western Hemisphere, including their activities, relationships with criminal organizations, and financial networks. The curr_chunk provides details on Iran's presence in the Western Hemisphere, including relationships with governments, law enforcement capabilities, and activity at the US borders with Mexico and Canada. The curr_chunk outlines operations at international borders in the Western Hemisphere, focusing on drug, human, and arms trafficking, support networks, financial aid, narco-tunneling, and technological advancements. It includes plans to secure the US border with Mexico and Canada, prevent operatives from Iran and terrorist organizations from entering the US, and coordinate multiagency action plans in Latin American countries with US allies and partners. The plan involves developing strong rule-of-law institutions for security in the region, counterterrorism measures to isolate Iran and its affiliated terrorist organizations, and addressing foreign assistance to Iran in evading sanctions. It also includes protecting US interests and assets in the Western Hemisphere. The strategy aims to counter threats to US allies, designate entities in the Western Hemisphere for proliferation and terrorist activities related to Iran, and ensure energy supplies free from foreign government influence. The Secretary of State will consult with relevant heads in developing the strategy. The Secretary of State will consult with relevant US departments and agencies, including Defense, Intelligence, Homeland Security, Treasury, and others. The strategy may be classified but must include an unclassified summary to address the Iranian threat in the Western Hemisphere. Congress urges the Secretary of State to keep committees informed on Iran's hostile actions in the region. This Act does not limit US citizens' rights under the Constitution or create additional authorities. The Act does not limit US citizens' rights under the Constitution or create additional authorities for the Federal Government that are contrary to the United States Constitution and United States law.
